Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project treats a central problem in many industrial and environmental flow simulations. Complex turbulence not at statistical equilibrium occurs in almost all engineering fluid flows. Its accurate simulation is essential for many critical applications, including global change estimation and energy efficiency optimization. For example, 85% of the energy in the U.S. is generated by combustion; energy efficiency optimization requires accurate simulation of turbulent mixing. However, there is little mathematical theory, few effective models, and no systematic computational practice for simulation of turbulent flows that are not at statistical equilibrium. This research project aims to develop mathematical models and computational algorithms to simulate such flows and to conduct a rigorous numerical analysis of the new models and algorithms. Several graduate students will participate in the project.

This project is to conduct research in numerical analysis on turbulence not at statistical equilibrium. The goal of the project is to extend current models and computational algorithms to turbulence not at statistical equilibrium, allowing for backscatter (energy flow from fluctuations back to means) without negative viscosities, and to develop mathematical support for the new models and algorithms. The research will develop, analyze, and test new models of turbulence adapted from models at statistical equilibrium and will develop new unconditionally nonlinearly stable, linearly implicit numerical methods for their approximation. The project represents a systematic attack on modeling and numerical analysis, broadly understood, of turbulence not at statistical equilibrium, investigating fundamental mathematical, modeling, and computational issues in its predictive simulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes

This project is to conduct research to build reliable computational and mathematical tools for the prediction of turbulent flows of fluids (liquids, gasses, plasmas). Turbulence is a phenomenon which is very common in scientific, technological, geophysical and engineering applications. It is also one where it is easier to list what is important but not known than to list what we do know.

Currently, the most effective models and computer codes work when the flow is at statistical equilibrium. This means the flow exhibits some sort of balance (on average) between power input and loss of power to heat. Flows not at statistical equilibrium are of great importance but little understood. Further, the first step in the most used models explicitly eliminates the possibility of non-equilibrium turbulence.

The research carried out took two common models and showed how to enlarge the models to flows not at statistical equilibrium. This means the models allow for backscatter (energy flow from fluctuations back to means), intermittence (spiky fluctuations in important flow quantities) and other important effects. Turbulence is a nonlinear phenomenon and turbulence models reflect that nonlinearity. Nonlinearity means that development has to be for specific models rather than a one size fits all universal model. Nevertheless, while the model extensions are specific the approach developed gives a road map to treat other models.

A second aspect of the research was to develop faster, more accurate numerical methods to be used on computers to produce predictions from the models. These improved numerical methods were developed to give time accurate flow predictions.

A third aspect of the project was to expand the workforce of computational scientists who have the training and ability to continue advancing the tools we have for prediction of processes in science, technology and engineering. A large number of young scientists were mentored, including ones from underrepresented groups. Each has developed into a formidable, independent researcher confident in their own abilities and with their own research agenda.

Improving the predictive power of turbulence models and developing the next generation of computational scientists in the area have clear impacts across science and engineering. The research was undertaken to emphasize reliability which requires a rigorous mathematical foundation to be developed at each step. The mathematical analysis of the equations of fluid motion at high Reynolds numbers is a problem famous for its mathematical depth and difficulty.  The intellectual merit of the research was that it was carried out with full rigor and created a mathematical architecture which can be further developed.
